Your seal of approval on a foundation is so important so I really appreciated this video. I wore Tir Tir for the first time today. I‚Äôm 78 with dry-combo skin in summer and since I‚Äôve been using Retin A for years, my skin is minimally wrinkled but I have labial and marionette lines around my mouth which foundations love to settle in. The TirTir looked a little makeupy on my forehead, but natural overall. It didn‚Äôt settle into lines or wrinkles. It‚Äôs tricky to apply though. If you press down enough to get product on the pad, it‚Äôs way too much to apply directly to skin. Rubbing the pad on the inside lid and then applying to face will still result in too heavy a coat. I learned to just pick up just the tiniest bit on the pad, then rub on the lid, then press the whole pad on the lid and then apply. I also tried using a damp sponge which I patted on the product left in the lid. Both those techniques gave me a more natural finish. It did last all day but got pretty glowy. I powdered lightly after 5 hours and it looked great. Unfortunately I got 27N and it‚Äôs a tad too dark & yellow for my skin tone so I ordered the sample kit from Amazon for less than $2 so I can try some different colors before I order again.

As a dry-combo/normal skin girlie, I am absolutely loving the TirTir Cushion Red (23N Sand) as it feels super secure, and hydrating and is probably a great option for those that have a similar skin type as I do, who prefer a natural matte finish.

I bounce around wearing dewy and natural/semi matte foundations depending on season, and I normally wear Haus Labs TriClone Foundation in Light Medium Neutral 210.

Another thing to note is that the TirTir foundation on first application may look pale upon first application, but trust the process as this foundation oxidizes pretty beautifully as you get the rest of your makeup done. I was pretty shocked at this at first to be honest. Make sure to also have a great hydrating skin prep before applying, and if you use setting powder, I recommend to opt out in using it as I noticed it adds unnecessary skin texture when I did so. A hydrating setting spray is much better imo.

My only current gripe with TirTir however is that I cannot seem to find any links or even a functioning official website for refills. I heard that the red cushion foundation is refillable, (could be wrong) and I prefer not purchasing a whole new mirror or puff just for foundation. First I dabbed the Tirtir on my acne scars. The ease with which this goes on is unbelievable. I then followed with the Bare Minerals powder in my skin tone to set, because of how hot and humid Savannah is. Lastly, I spritzed the Tula Signature Glow Face Mist over my whole face. This foundation looked skin like and was flawless after 17 hours of wear in a hot climate, where I sweated all day as I was out and about touring the city. We ended up at a Taco spot at 2AM and when I went to the ladies room and stared into the mirror, I could not believe how amazing it looked. Its as if it became more skin like as time passed and still covered my scars. What sort of witchcraft is this?

i know as a westerner it sounds weird for a brands mission to be merging science and nature (haven't we heard it a million times before from western brands who legitimately don't even try to live up to the statement - see insert essential plant oild at bottom of ingredients list) so i definitely get it sounds odd. however if you look at it through the lens of Korean culture and how Koreans developed their skin care, their influences etc, i think it does make sense. Koreans are really big on Hanbang skin care, which is skincare methods and formulas derived straight from ingredients found in nature (mugwort and centella are two pretty big ones and popular atm) - a brand that does this really well and that has really had a chance to solidify it's identity with that is BOJ. but if you look at most popular Korean skincare brands, they are inspired by the same history and have similar approaches to using the power of ingredients derived from natural sources. i think maybe tirtir is a bit more hesitant to really embrace the Korean terminology and history too strongly here in-case it alienates their international customer base (and remember they did start out with make up and that seems to be their main focus) so they went with a purpose statement that was a bit more appealing or easier for a wide range of cultures and people to grasp but they also lost a little bit of what makes K skincare special in the first place by doing that. i think they really could do awesome things with their skincare products if they follow a little more in BOJ's footsteps and really embrace their Korean identity in and international capacity a bit more.

When it comes to the bag, my first thought was about korean culture. One of best friends is korean and when she came to visit me, she got gifts for her family and the monotary value was the most important aspect. The gift needed to be a recognized luxery brand. It was weird as an american who grew up on the phrase "its the thought that counts" but thats just culture. I really think the birkin controversy is just a big cultural misunderstanding (they they hopefully learned from)

A few notes on some of the side elements discussing the brand. First this brand isn't commonly seen in cosmetics stores in Seoul. Having recently been there I saw no stores I could find aside from something I saw on Google maps in Gangnam that didn't appear to exist in person. I saw tons of cosmetics stores, but only 1-2 had TirTir products and it was a very trimmed down selection smaller than what I've seen here other than the cushion that I saw in a few places. In Japan I actually saw a pop-up, but it was closed for a private event (possibly exclusive).

As far as the culture, I can't speak that much from a one day visit, but the marketing in S. Korea seemed far more focused on unattainable perfection. I saw a picture of a shirtless photoshopped guy with 8-pack abs to sell glasses (not sunglasses, the ones to help you actually see). The luxury culture seems baked in, but only to a specific subset of the population, and there are entire markets devoted to "luxury" goods that are really just fakes for $20-40. Having also seen Japan that actually feels like it has a stronger luxury brand culture, I just feel its less in your face than the brand focus portions of Seoul that can almost be equated to portions of LA.

title: Worth the Hype? | Tirtir Mask Fit Cushion Foundation (Wear Test)
description: Why is the Tirtir Mask Fit Cushion Foundation so viral right now? Is it worth the hype and how does wear after eight hours on oily ...
comments: I agree, I‚Äôm so undecided on this. I ordered the sample packs as well and I thought I nailed down my shade. I‚Äôve landed on mocha and then I wore it and I felt like it was way too light for my skin now I‚Äôm confused on which color again, and I‚Äôm not sure if I like the way it wears but the correct shade could change my mind.

I also bought the shade trial kits, too. It was very difficult to guess online. Unfortunately, I did not find a perfect match either. Too many "neutral" shades and some were looking warm or orange! I am currently medium tanned skin with warm undertones. 27C looked like my winter shade as it was a little warmer than expected but slightly neutral, however still got a good match. So my current summer shade is 27C & 33W mixed together. My winter shade could be 27C & 30N mixed. 30N was very orange! I use Nars barcelona foundation, ginger/biscuit concealer, Huda Beauty tres leches foundation, granola concealer, Estee Lauder fawn/cashew foundation, 3w/4w concealer shades for reference if anyone is struggling finding their Tirtir shade.

heres a little tip on applying cushion foundations!
ok so when you take the little cushion puff and start to dab it into the foundation, you want to make sure to get the middle of the puff. also, whenever you open the foundation there should be like a little lid that protects the foundation. wherever you dab your puff into the foundation, you then want to dab your puff 1-2 times on the lid to get a more even finish. hope this helps!!

By the way, according to some reviews, I pressed the puff very lightly against the sponge and then tapped it on my face in a few places, as you would with a standard foundation, and then spread it all over with my hands. But if I would use more product, I would have spread it with a brush.
As you have demonstrated, the foundation stays put and beautiful all day, well at least for 10 hours.
The price if this foundation on Yesstyle varies all the time, but it is very reasonable for what it is. I would say US$20 or around ¬£16 in the UK.

For the love of all things holy please learn to use this foundation correctly when providing a review and feedback. Too often individuals reviewing this foundation goes straight into it and applied directly to their face. That is not how you apply this foundation. You dip the applicator into the product and then pat off the excess on the back of the lid. Then apply when you apply this product in the manner that she is applying it you end up with a substantial amount of product on your face that should not be there with correct application. The amount of product that was placed on her face during this review was enough product for two weeks of every day whereas it was not applied correctly. So please prior to giving a review do your homework and provide feedback based upon application.

title: #1 BEST SELLING Foundation?!! üò≤ | Viral TIRTIR Cushion Foundation *UNSPONSORED* | 2 Week Wear!
description: Let's test out Japan's #1 Foundation! ‚ÄºÔ∏èNOT SPONSORED‚ÄºÔ∏è ‚ù• Bought Myself! #tirtir #viralmakeup #cushionfoundation ...
comments:
Hi Glamfam! Happy National Asian Heritage month to all my Asian Glamfam sisters! Representing my daddy's (Japanese) side it was fun to honor an asian owned brand and to personally know how popular this is in Japan! Avorie was able to tell me that it's literally everywhere in Japan that she goes! Many others read the claims and talking points on how this is #1 seller in Japan but we personally know someone to witness that and give us that feedback which is awesome! Avorie knew about this well before social media made it popular and sorry it took me so long Amber to review this! I hope to someday be able to visit Japan! üáØüáµ This blew up on Tiktok and thanks to the incredible asian influencers on that platform and the amazing and talented Robert Welsh on YouTube! Then every other big influencer jumped on and spread the word TirTir even more!! Putting this K-beauty brand on the map! But being an Asian YouTuber (over 46), it was fun to review this from my perspective and hopefully help others make a decision on whether this was right for them! I will give you my update below on how often I use this. Also Regina and Amber both bought this on YesStyle ‚û§https://rstyle.me/+rU8FkxolQYJd2_WkUpkmag and you can get a sample for like a $1 so maybe try that first but always remember Amazon returns quite easy if you can find your shade prime that's the tricky part!

Update:
I don't wear full coverage foundations on a normal basis and I personally still love my Maybelline skin plus vitamin c the most and then Surratt for special occasions but sometimes I will use this more as a spot conceal and like that better than concealer! I do use this very sparingly but for the purpose of trying this video I used a lot! So my recommendation moving forward is go more sparingly especially with mature skin and that is a bit easier sometime with a brush and then sponge to blend out. I will play with this more in real life and maybe even on another video.I will probably have to up the shade to 24w if I get tanned more during the summer months! I may buy that sample just to test out other shades. ‚ù§

title: SULWHASOO: My Updated Thoughts on this ~Luxury~ Korean Skin Care Brand!
description: Timestamps/Affiliate Links Below Where to Purchase: Sephora - https://howl.me/cmFY5Ubcxmg Stylevana ...
comments:
I really like Sulwhasoo and yeah I basically just buy minis from Stylevana sometimes in the 50% off weekly sales. Of note, the timetreasure line is being discontinued (or has already been discontinued) and replaced by the "S" line as per the flagship store in Seoul. Not entirely ideal since their creamy cleanser doesn't seem to have a replacement, but as long as the Amorepacific one stays I'm good to go. Speaking of Amorepacific, Sulwhasoo is owned by AmorePacific and aside from fragrance and the focus on ginseng the products are very similar so if you've tried one and are wondering about the other you probably have a good idea of your first impression. As far as specifics, the activating serum and toners are interesting for me in that I don't like them unless I have multiple toner steps in my routine. I think this mitigates some of the heavy alcohol implications (specifically with product absorption) which works for my routine but isn't necessarily a net positive. I'm with you on cleansing products they were fine, even good, but not my holy grails and I do feel the moisturizer line you referenced are my favorite products. The remaining serums are also very high performing skin supplements, but they just can't do what a tret or l-ascorbic acid will achieve.

End of the day, I can get 50ml of moisturizer for $40 or less and full amounts of serums for $50-60 or less by buying the samples. To me the value is there, but it's on each individual to determine whether its how they can an want to spend their money

title: Testing out luxury skincare for a month... is it worth your money?
description: As a girly with sensitive acne-prone skin, I wanted to test Sephora's top rated luxury brands and some luxe Korean luxury skincare ...
comments: Ok if Lamer was bought... Dior is still French and was never American. Its confusing because you're talking about trying Korean skincare vs American while using basically French and German brands.

I‚Äôve been using luxury products for about 18 months now. I‚Äôve gone through routines from, La Mer, Sulwhasoo, SK-II, Shiseido, Tatcha, and The History of Whoo. And depending on one‚Äôs skin issues, it does take more than a month to see drastic positive change. And as mentioned, it‚Äôs best to stay loyal to a brand than mixing and matching too much. My tip is to have one brand as a core, and maybe have 1-2 products that isn‚Äôt from the brand, like a face wash and an active. One thing to note is that most luxury skincare is aimed towards more mature skin, or people in their 30s. Starting early doesn‚Äôt hurt, just be mindful that one won‚Äôt see results right away and that textures will usually be on the heavier side even when they‚Äôre supposedly for oily skin.

I honestly think luxury beauty is worth it. It truly works on increasing resilience in the skin which lessens breakouts and slows down aging without the use of strong exfoliants or retinoids. But it takes time to see this effect. Like more than 6 months of consistent use. My skin has only had a major breakout during this time, which was due to traveling and less than good diet.

My honest thoughts is that any luxury brand will do! You just have to find one that speaks with your skin and find the products for your skin type. Just because one cream feels heavy doesn‚Äôt mean the whole brand is a waste. Pick one brand and stick to it. My personal favorite is Shiseido, their formulas and textures are top notch. Love Sulwhasoo, but it‚Äôs not as readily available for me. I hate to say it, but La Mer, the cream, there‚Äôs something magic about it. I use it more as a night treatment once a week during winter and can do with one of the smaller jars. I like the simplicity of a SK-II skincare routine, but their cream and serum is very heavily fragranced, so I only endorse the Pitera essence and their face wash. Honestly, more people should talk about their face wash.

You have to try Savef Skin Essential Face Serum- luxury serum.witout fragrance, no nonsense. Please try something new! It's $155 and it is amazing. Evens my skin hydrates, and I have no hormonal break outs??? Real Skin Retinue is the brand only one product! üòä
La merüëéüëéüëéüëé

I‚Äôm sorry you missed this, but most of the products you used were not American. Augustinus Bader is German, La Mer is also German, Sulwhasoo is Korean, SK-II is Japanese, and Dior is French. The only products you used that were American were from Shani Darden, which you said you liked. Almost every single luxury brand that‚Äôs popular in America is from other countries like France or Italy.

That being said, I‚Äôve tried a lot of these products and I totally agree with you, the only ones that are really worth it are the Sulwhasoo and Shani Darden. Dior‚Äôs skincare is kind of a flop and the rest are just so expensive and not worth it tbh.

I started using korean skincare back in 2016 and I noticed a big positive change in my skin. I think it's because korean skincare makes it known to the buyer what the ingredients are and what they are for. This helped me learn what ingredients works for my skin and which ingredients do not. Korean skincare really helped me learn about skincare ingredients which I now carry over to American skincare products when purchasing.

I‚Äôm Asian, but not from Japan, and I remember my GREAT grandmother sitting me down at the kitchen table with a mirror in front of me when I was as young as 6 or 7 years old all the way up until she died when I was 17. She lived in the US, but couldn‚Äôt speak English, and while she was proud of my educational goals, she REALLY, REALLY thought it was important that I focus on my skin, my nails, my hair, and my weight lol. I know she really wanted me to practice my techniques over and over again, as she thought that would guarantee me a man in life. ü§£

We would do ‚Äúlessons‚Äù in front of that mirror for hours a week and I learned how to contour before contouring was even a thing. I knew how to pluck and shape the most perfect eyebrows. I knew how to use eyeshadow to make it appear like I actually had eyelids.

I have so many hours and so much experience, I could easily be a hair stylist and a makeup artist.

My great grandma SWORE by Shiseido products, and they are amazing, and I still use a lot of them today.

They are very expensive compared to your drug store brands, so I don‚Äôt use them for every part of my face routine.

There is one product I buy religiously, and I honestly don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs better than cheaper products, but I know it smells just like my great grandma used to so I can‚Äôt stop purchasing it! It‚Äôs $140 for the cream, which is a bit much, but it‚Äôs worth it for the smell and memories!!!
